Literature Review: The discovery of bridge-like lipid transport proteins has revolutionized our understanding of lipid transport in eukaryotic cells. These proteins, which belong to the VPS13 family, possess a unique RBG motif that enables them to transport lipids across membranes. The structure and localization of these proteins at membrane contact sites suggest a bridge-like mechanism of lipid transport, which is distinct from the shuttle-like mechanisms previously thought to be mediated by lipid transfer proteins (LTPs). In this review, we will discuss the known properties and physiological roles of these proteins, as well as the many questions that remain open about their functions.
